Kuota FLPP Habis, Pembangunan Rumah Bersubsidi Tersendat
06 Nov 2019, 23:15 by Larissa Huda, Ali Akhmad Noor Hidayat
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Sekretaris Jenderal Dewan Pimpinan Pusat Asosiasi Pengembang Perumahan dan Pemukiman Seluruh Indonesia (Apersi)Daniel Djumali menuturkan saat ini kuota pembiayaan rumah bersubsidi dengan Kredit Perumahan Rakyat (KPR) skema Fasilitas Likuiditas Pembiayaan Perumahan (FLPP) telah habis. Hal ini, kata dia, akan berdampak pada kinerja perusahaan.
“Hal ini berpengaruh bagi arus pengembang, karena rumah yang sudah selesai dibangun tidak bisa diakadkan,” tutur Daniel kepada Tempo, Rabu 6 November 2019.
Daniel mencontohkan apabila ada 20 ribu unit rumah yang akan diakadkan dikali Rp 140 juta, artinya akan nada investasi yang tersendat sekitar Rp 2,8 triliun. Padahal, kata dia, sektor perumahan berkaitan langsung dengan 120 komponen bisnis lainnya, baik material, tenaga kerja, dan lainnya. Selain itu, Daniel menilai investasi dari luar negeri juga akan tersendat lantaran habisnya kuota rumah bersubsidi FLPP.
“Dalam sejarahnya, baru kali ini terjadi kelangkaan atau habis nya kuota rumah bersubsidi. Hal ini juga berdampak buruk bagi konsumen masyarakat berpenghasilan rendah yang sudah membayar lunas uang muka, tapi tidak bisa ditempati atau diakad,” kata dia.
Setidaknya tiga asosiasi pengembang, kata Daniel, sudah menemui pemerintah, baik Kementerian Pekerjaan Umum dan Perumahan Rakyat (PUPR), Kementerian Keuangan, hingga Presiden Joko Widodo untuk meminta tambahan kuota rumah bersubsidi. Daniel menuturkan pemerintah menjanjikan tambahan kuota. “Mudah-mudahan, kuota tambahan rumah bersubsidi FLPP ini, bisa terealisasi,” ujar Daniel.
Ketua Umum Himpunan Pengembang Pemukiman dan Perumahan Rakyat (Himperra) Endang Kawidjaja menuturkan habisnya kuota ini akan membuat konsumen terhambat untuk melakukan akad. Konsumen yang mau pindah ke skema komersil hanya sekitar 1-2 persen dari mereka yang tidak mendapatkan kuota. Menurut dia, kebanyakan masyarakat berpenghasilan rendah enggan memilih skema komersil lantaran harganya yang lebih mahal.
“Mereka tidak mungkin mampu dari segi cicilannya. Bayankan KPR lewat FLPP cicilannya hanya Rp 800 ribu, kalau yang komersil selisih 450 ribu atau 60 persen lebih mahal,” tutur Endang.

FLPP Quota Exhausted, Construction of Subsidized Houses faltered
Nov 6 2019, 23:15 by Larissa Huda, Ali Akhmad Noor Hidayat
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Secretary General of the Indonesian Central Board of Housing and Settlement Developers Association (Apersi) Daniel Djumali said that currently the quota for subsidized housing financing with the People's Housing Credit (KPR) Housing Financing Liquidity Facility (FLPP) scheme has expired. This, he said, will have an impact on company performance.
"This has an effect on the flow of developers, because houses that have already been completed cannot be built," Daniel told Tempo, Wednesday, November 6, 2019.
Daniel gave an example if there were 20 thousand housing units that would be built multiplied by Rp. 140 million, meaning that the investment tone would be stalled around Rp. 2.8 trillion. In fact, he said, the housing sector is directly related to 120 other business components, both material, labor, and others. In addition, Daniel assesses that investment from abroad will also be hampered due to the exhaustion of the FLPP subsidized housing quota.
"In history, this is the first time that scarcity or subsidized housing quota has run out. This also has a negative impact on low-income consumers who have paid in advance, but cannot be occupied or contracted, "he said.
At least three developer associations, said Daniel, have met with the government, both the Ministry of Public Works and Public Housing (PUPR), the Ministry of Finance, and President Joko Widodo to request additional subsidized housing quotas. Daniel said the government promised an additional quota. "Hopefully, this additional quota of FLPP subsidized houses can be realized," Daniel said.
Chairperson of the Public Settlement and Housing Development Association (Himperra) Endang Kawidjaja said that the end of this quota would hamper consumers from entering into a contract. Consumers who want to move to commercial schemes are only around 1-2 percent of those who do not get a quota. According to him, most low-income people are reluctant to choose commercial schemes because the price is more expensive.
"They might not be able in terms of installments. Imagine KPR through FLPP, the installment is only Rp. 800 thousand, if the commercial difference is 450 thousand or 60 percent more expensive, "said Endang.
